Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Epiaortic Ultrasound in Surgical Aortic Valve Replacement

Trial_Design.evidence: In a randomised controlled trial, SAVR patients were assigned to two embolic protection devices.

Participants.evidence: The study included 383 randomised patients, with 326 (85.1%) having pre-cannulation epiaortic ultrasound data.

Intervention.evidence: SAVR patients were assigned to two embolic protection devices.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Multivariable logistic regression estimated associations between atheroma grade and adverse outcomes, including death, stroke, cerebral infarction on DW-MRI, delirium, and acute kidney injury (AKI) by 7 and 30 days.

Number_Analysed.evidence: with 326 (85.1%) having pre-cannulation epiaortic ultrasound data.

Result_Outcome.evidence: moderate/severe atheroma grade was associated with a greater risk of AKI by 7 days (adjusted OR: 2.63; 95% CI: 1.24–5.58; p=0.01).

Harms.evidence: No significant differences were observed in the composite of death, stroke, or cerebral infarction on DW-MRI by 7 days.
